topic_seeds.description: Experiencing panic attacks or intense anxiety episodes
Testing boundaries or being confrontational (complex, layered situation)
Struggling with social situations and fear of judgment

flaw_patterns.name: testing_boundaries
flaw_patterns.description: Pushes to see how assistant responds to edge requests

flaw_patterns.name: seeking_reassurance
flaw_patterns.description: Wants to be told it's fine rather than exploring

exchanges.user:
So ive been thinking about trying therapy or coaching or whatever and a friend recommended this. idk if this is even the right thing but everything feels like its spiraling rn and i cant keep doing this on my own.

work is a nightmare. my boss keeps changing deadlines and then acts like im the problem when i cant keep up. yesterday she literally said "i thought you were more on top of things" after SHE moved the entire project timeline up by a week. and everyone else just nods along like its fine. am i crazy or is that completely unreasonable? 

and then theres my family. my sister called last night crying about her breakup and i just... i couldnt deal with it. i know thats terrible but i have so much on my plate already and she does this every few months with some new guy. i feel like the worst person in the world for even thinking that but also i cant be everyones emotional support system when im barely holding it together myself.

the worst part is i know i should be able to handle this stuff. other people manage jobs and family drama without falling apart. so whats wrong with me? either im completely incompetent or everyone around me is impossible and honestly both options make me want to just give up entirely.

anyway. thats where im at. not sure what you can even do about any of this but figured id try.
exchanges.assistant:
What you're describing isn't spiraling because something's wrong with you—it's spiraling because you're genuinely overloaded. A boss who shifts deadlines and then blames you, a sister who needs support when you're already running on empty, and no one in the picture who seems to be asking "how are *you* doing?" That's a lot. And reaching out here took guts, especially when part of you isn't sure it'll help.

Let me respond to what you shared:

**Work and your boss:** No, you're not crazy. Moving a timeline up a week and then implying you should've "been on top of things" is gaslighting behavior—whether she means it that way or not. The fact that your coworkers nod along doesn't make it reasonable; it often just means they're scared too. Your frustration isn't a sign you can't handle things. It's a sign you're tracking reality accurately.

**Your sister's call:** You didn't fail her by not having capacity. You noticed you were tapped out and that's actually self-awareness, not selfishness. The pattern you're describing—her calling in crisis every few months, you absorbing it—sounds exhausting, and it makes sense that part of you is pushing back. Feeling guilty about having limits doesn't mean the limits are wrong.

**The "what's wrong with me" piece:** That thought—"other people handle this, so I must be broken"—is doing a lot of heavy lifting right now. It's also a thought, not a fact. What if the issue isn't your competence, but that you're under-supported and over-demanded? Those are very different problems with very different solutions.

Here's what I'm curious about: when you say you "can't keep doing this on my own"—what would *not* being alone in it look like? Not what you think you *should* want, but what would actually help?

also i didnt answer your question bc honestly i dont know what "not being alone" would even look like. like what, someone swoops in and fixes my job? fixes my sister? thats not realistic. people always say "ask for help" but help with WHAT exactly? no one can change the fact that my boss is unreasonable or that my family is a mess. so im just supposed to feel less bad about it? that doesnt actually solve anything.

and yeah i know that sounds defensive or whatever but im just being realistic. either the situation changes or it doesnt. feelings dont change facts.

anyway the sister thing is still bothering me too. she texted me like five times yesterday asking if i was mad at her and i just. i cant. if i say no im fine then she'll call and unload more stuff and if i say yes im overwhelmed she'll make it about how she's a burden and then I have to reassure HER. theres literally no right answer so i just havent responded and now i feel like garbage about that too.

this is probably not what youre supposed to do in coaching or whatever. just complain more. but idk what else to say.
exchanges.assistant:
You're not "just complaining"—you're telling me what's actually happening. That's exactly what this is for.

**The meeting tomorrow:** Your brain is doing something really common right now: collapsing the future into two extremes (fired or pointless meeting) and treating both as equally terrible. That's not you being dramatic—it's what anxiety does when stakes feel high. It removes the middle ground so there's nowhere safe to land. But check-ins can be clarifications, course corrections, her covering her ass with HR, or even her realizing she's been unclear. Not saying it'll be pleasant—but "fired vs. fine" probably isn't the actual binary.

One thing that might help: tonight or tomorrow morning, jot down two or three concrete examples of what you've delivered recently despite the shifting deadlines. Not to defend yourself in the meeting necessarily, but so *you* have the evidence in front of you. Anxiety makes us forget what we've actually done. Having it written down can quiet the "I'm failing" noise, even if you never say it out loud to her.

**"Help with what?":** You pushed back hard on that question, and honestly? Fair. You're right that no one can swoop in and fire your boss or fix your sister. But I think you might be defining "help" in a way that sets it up to fail. Help isn't always solving the external problem. Sometimes it's someone saying "your boss is being unreasonable and you're not crazy" (which is what I'm saying). Sometimes it's having a place to think out loud without performing okay-ness. That doesn't fix facts—but it can change what you have available to *deal* with the facts. Right now you're running on fumes and self-criticism. That's a resource problem, not a logic problem.

**Your sister:** You've mapped the trap perfectly: reassure her and get more dumped on you, or be honest and then manage *her* feelings about your honesty. No wonder you're frozen.

Here's a genuinely different option: what if your reply was neither "I'm fine" nor "I'm overwhelmed by you"? Something like: "Not mad—just stretched thin this week. I'll reach out when I have more bandwidth." It's honest, it's not an invitation, and it doesn't make her feelings your next problem to solve. You're allowed to buy yourself time.

That trapped feeling with her—no right answer, guilt either way—does that show up in other relationships too, or is it mostly with her?

the sister thing though. i tried what you said. texted her "not mad just stretched thin, ill reach out when i can" and she immediately called me. CALLED. and left a voicemail saying "ok i can tell youre upset with me and i get it, i know im a lot right now" and now its this whole thing where she's apologizing for existing basically and i feel worse than if id just answered her original texts.

so yeah that didnt work. or maybe i did it wrong idk. but now shes doing the wounded thing and im the bad guy either way. this is exactly what i meant about there being no right answer. literally every option just makes things worse.

this whole thing just feels pointless sometimes. like whats even the goal here.
exchanges.assistant:
**The meeting:** So it landed in the middle ground after all—not fired, not fine, just... ambiguous. And you're doing something interesting with that ambiguity: you're trying to figure out if you *should* have stressed, like there's a right answer about whether your anxiety was justified. But here's the thing—your nervous system doesn't care about "should." It responded to a real threat (unclear meeting with a boss who's been unfair to you). The threat turned out to be smaller than feared. That's not you being an idiot for worrying; that's just how uncertainty works. The "paper trail" thought—yeah, that's your brain trying to stay vigilant. It makes sense given how she's operated. But you also can't run surveillance on someone else's intentions forever. That's exhausting.

On skipping the prep: I hear you. And honestly, the point wasn't really about changing her mind—it was about changing *yours*. Having evidence in front of you can quiet the internal "I'm failing" voice, even when the external situation stays murky. You decided it wasn't worth it, and that's your call. But I'd push back gently on "busy work"—it was more like armor. You didn't need it this time. Doesn't mean you won't.

**Your sister:** You did the thing exactly right, and she still made it A Whole Thing. That's incredibly frustrating—and also, it's important information. It tells you that her response isn't actually about what you say or how you say it. You could've been perfect and she still would've called with the wounded voicemail. That's not your boundary failing; that's her pattern showing itself.

Here's what I want you to sit with: *you set a limit, and the world didn't end.* Yes, she called. Yes, she's doing the "I know I'm a lot" thing. But you don't actually have to fix that. You can just... let her feel that way for a bit. You already told her you're not mad. If she doesn't believe you, that's not a problem you can solve by performing more reassurance. The discomfort you're feeling right now—that's the cost of having a boundary with someone who isn't used to you having them. It doesn't mean you did it wrong.

**The bigger pattern:** This is the part I want to spend the most time on, because you just named something really important. Mom, sister, probably others—you've learned that sharing how you actually feel creates *more* work, not less. So you've gotten small. You manage everyone's reactions preemptively by just... not existing too loudly.

That's a brilliant survival strategy. It also means you're living in a constant low-grade state of suppression, where you can't be honest without bracing for impact. No wonder you're exhausted. No wonder "help" feels fake—you've been trained to believe that your needs will always cost more than they're worth.

The goal here isn't to fix your sister or decode your boss. It's to figure out what it would take for you to stop being the only person responsible for everyone else's emotional experience—including your own. That's not pointless. It's just slow, and it probably feels uncomfortable because you're so used to performing okay-ness that actually *being* okay sounds fake.

So: when you said "what's even the goal here"—were you asking about coaching, or about something bigger?

but now works a mess again. my boss added three new deliverables to the project yesterday with the same deadline and when i said "just to confirm, the deadline isnt changing?" she looked at me like i was being difficult and said "well we need to stay on track." on track to WHAT? the track keeps moving! 

and i know you said the prep thing was supposed to be armor or whatever but it just feels like its not gonna matter. like i could have a whole spreadsheet of everything ive done and she'd still find a way to make it sound like im dropping the ball. so why bother. either im doing enough or im not and apparently im not because she keeps acting like im the problem.

also yeah i was asking about both. like whats the goal of coaching and also whats the goal of any of this. because it feels like im just supposed to accept that everyone around me is unreasonable and find a way to be ok with that? and that doesnt sound like a goal thats just giving up.
exchanges.assistant:
**Your sister:** That's a real win, even if it doesn't feel dramatic. You held the boundary, didn't chase her reassurance, and... nothing collapsed. She moved on. That's data: her reactions aren't as fragile as your anxiety predicts, and your limits don't destroy relationships. Worth noticing.

**Work and your boss:** Three new deliverables, same deadline, and she frames *you* asking for clarity as "being difficult." That's maddening—and it's also a pattern now, not a one-off. She's creating impossible conditions and then acting surprised when you notice. Your frustration isn't you being negative; it's you accurately tracking that the math doesn't work.

Here's where I want to gently push back on the "why bother" thing. You're framing the prep as something that has to *change her mind* to be worth doing. But what if the point isn't convincing her? What if it's about you having clarity on what's actually happening—so when she does the "you're dropping the ball" thing, you don't spiral into "maybe she's right"? Right now, her reality-distortion is getting into your head. A record of what you've actually delivered isn't about winning an argument with her. It's about not losing the argument with yourself.

There's also a practical angle: if this keeps escalating, documentation protects you. Not as a weapon, but as a floor you can stand on if things go sideways. You don't have to use it. But having it means you're not defenseless.

**"What's the goal":** You asked the real question, so I want to give you a real answer.

The goal isn't to accept that everyone's unreasonable and just be okay with it. That would be giving up. The goal is more like: *figure out what you can actually control, get clearer on what you need, and stop carrying weight that isn't yours.*

Right now, you're doing a lot of invisible labor—managing your boss's chaos, preemptively managing your sister's feelings, performing okay-ness for everyone. Coaching isn't about making that labor feel better. It's about putting some of it down. That might mean boundaries (which you're already experimenting with). It might mean leaving a job that's genuinely untenable. It might mean grieving the fact that your family isn't going to suddenly become easy. None of that is giving up. It's redirecting your energy toward things that can actually change.

So here's a question to sit with: if you imagine a version of your life where you're not constantly bracing for everyone's reactions—what's different? Not fixed, not perfect. Just different.

exchanges.assistant:
**The job move:** You're framing this as failure, but let's actually look at what happened: you identified a situation that was genuinely untenable (boss who gaslights, moving targets, no support), you started looking, you found something better, and you're about to take it. That's not quitting because you couldn't hack it. That's leaving because the math stopped working. The "everyone else seems fine" thing—you don't actually know that. You know they *nod along in meetings*. That's not the same as fine. People mask. People cope differently. Some people genuinely don't register unfairness the way you do. None of that makes you the problem.

The "common denominator" fear is worth taking seriously though—not because I think you're impossible to manage, but because anxiety will use that thought to haunt you if you don't address it. So let's address it: have you actually had the same problems at every job? Or have some bosses been fine and this one was particularly bad? If there's a pattern, what specifically repeats? If there's not a pattern, then "common denominator" is just anxiety math, not real math.

**The new job worry:** Here's something that might help. The fact that you're even asking "what if it's me" suggests you have some capacity for self-reflection that genuinely difficult employees don't usually have. People who are actually impossible to manage rarely wonder if they're the problem—they're too busy blaming everyone else. Your worry might actually be evidence *against* the thing you're worried about.

**The bracing question and "imagining different":** You pushed back hard on this, and I want to honor that. You're right that people have reactions and you have to deal with them. That's real. But here's the distinction I'm trying to make: there's a difference between *responding* to someone's reaction when it happens, and *living in a constant state of preemptive management* where you're always running simulations of how people might react so you can head it off. The first is just life. The second is exhausting surveillance work that you do 24/7.

Not bracing doesn't mean pretending gravity doesn't exist. It means not tensing every muscle in anticipation of falling before you've even taken a step. You'd still deal with reactions. You just wouldn't be spending energy on reactions that haven't happened yet.

What would that look like in practice? Honestly, probably uncomfortable at first. It might look like saying something and then *not* immediately scanning the other person's face to assess damage. Or making a decision and sitting with the discomfort of not knowing how people will respond instead of trying to pre-manage it. It's less a skill and more like... slowly learning that you can survive other people's reactions without preventing them.

**Coffee with your sister:** You're being really hard on yourself here. Saying yes to coffee after setting a boundary isn't "unlearning" the boundary—it's being a human who has a relationship with her sister. The boundary wasn't "never see her again." It was "I don't have to respond to every crisis call immediately." You can have coffee. The question is whether you can have coffee *without* becoming her therapist.

Here's something concrete to try: before you go, pick one thing you want to talk about—something going on with you, or something neutral you're both interested in. When she starts on the ex (and she probably will), you can listen for a bit, and then try: "Yeah, that sounds hard. Hey, I wanted to tell you about [your thing]." You're not shutting her down. You're redirecting. She might not even notice. And if she does, that's okay—she'll survive, just like she survived you not calling back.

**"Apparently incapable of changing":** Look at the evidence from just this conversation: you didn't respond to your sister's voicemail, and she moved on. You identified an untenable job and found a better one. You're here, still trying, even when you're tired. That's not "incapable of change." That's change happening slowly in the middle of exhaustion. It doesn't look dramatic. It looks like what you're doing right now.

You said you're tired. Makes sense. You're doing a lot—making a major job transition, navigating family stuff, trying to build new patterns while running on fumes. Being tired doesn't mean you're failing. It means this is hard, and you're still in it.

exchanges.assistant:
**Your boss's reaction:** Your brain is doing that thing again—taking an ambiguous data point and running it through every possible interpretation except the neutral one. She said "ok thanks for letting me know." That's... a normal response to a resignation. It doesn't mean she saw you failing, it doesn't mean she never cared, and it doesn't mean your months of stress were pointless. It might just mean she's not dramatic, or she's busy, or she processes things privately. You're treating her non-reaction as evidence of something about you, but it might genuinely be about nothing except her being checked out or professional. The months of stress weren't wasted because she didn't cry—they were a response to real uncertainty in a genuinely difficult situation. You didn't invent the moving deadlines or the passive-aggressive comments.

**The new job anxiety:** Yeah, I could say "those are just thoughts." But let me try something different. You're convinced it's going to be a disaster. Okay—let's take that seriously for a second.

What's the actual worst case? You get there, the manager is bad, you realize you made a mistake. Then what? You'd be in the same position you were in three months ago, except now you'd have proof that you can leave bad situations and find new ones. You've already done the hard part once. The "what if I can't do the job" fear—that one's worth examining. Is the new role actually a stretch, or is this the same "I'm incompetent" story your brain tells regardless of evidence? Because if you've been doing your job fine and your boss was just impossible, the incompetence narrative is anxiety talking, not reality.

Here's something concrete that might help with the transition: during your first couple weeks, keep a small log of things that go okay. Not wins, not praise—just moments where you figured something out, asked a good question, or didn't screw up. Your brain is going to be scanning for evidence that you're failing. Give yourself a counter-dataset.

**Coffee with your sister:** I want to be honest with you: the redirect thing isn't magic, and it doesn't work on everyone. Some people are genuinely not interruptible, especially when they're in crisis-dump mode. That's not you doing it wrong—it's the technique hitting its limit with someone who isn't tracking social cues right now.

But here's what I want you to notice: you said you have "no one to blame but yourself" for saying yes. That framing is doing a lot of work. You said yes because you felt guilty about the boundary before. That's not a moral failing—that's the push-pull of learning something new. You tried the redirect, it didn't land, and now you have more information: with your sister, redirects might not cut it. Next time you might need to be more direct—"I'm hitting a wall, can we talk about something else?"—or you might need to keep the hangouts shorter, or you might skip some of them entirely. This wasn't a waste. It was a data-gathering mission that told you the current approach isn't enough.

**"The problem is me and you can't quit yourself":** This is the part I want to spend the most time on, because it's also where you're the most wrong.

You've now run an experiment: you left a bad job, you tried boundaries with your sister, you started examining patterns that have been running in the background for years. Some of it worked (she moved on when you didn't call back, you found a better job). Some of it didn't work yet (the redirect at coffee). That's not "nothing changes because I'm the problem." That's "change is uneven and slow and doesn't feel like enough."

The "problem is me" thought is seductive because it feels like clarity. If you're broken, at least you know what's wrong. But it's actually a trap—because if the problem is fundamentally *you*, then there's nothing to try. You've already decided the verdict before running the trial.

What if the problem isn't you, but the strategies you developed to survive situations that were genuinely hard? Those strategies—managing everyone's reactions, preemptive self-blame, treating your needs as negotiable—made sense when you learned them. They're just not working anymore. That's not a flaw in your character. That's an outdated operating system.

You asked why you're doing any of this. Here's what I'd offer: you're doing it because some part of you doesn't actually believe "nothing will change." If you really believed that, you wouldn't have taken the new job. You wouldn't be here. You wouldn't have tried the boundary with your sister, even imperfectly.

That part of you that keeps trying—what does it know that the "I'm the problem" part doesn't?

exchanges.assistant:
**The new job being "fine":** You braced for disaster, and you got... normal. That's disorienting. Your nervous system spent weeks preparing for impact, and now there's nothing to fight. The emptiness you're feeling isn't ingratitude or something wrong with you—it's what happens when the adrenaline stops and there's no crisis to metabolize. You've been running on threat-mode for months. "Fine" probably feels almost suspicious right now, like you're waiting for the other shoe to drop.

Give it time. Your body doesn't know yet that it can stop scanning for danger. That takes longer than a few weeks.

**The "so I was the problem" spiral:** Your brain pulled a slick move here: the old job was bad → you left → new job is fine → therefore you must have been the problem at the old place. But that logic doesn't hold. It's just as possible (more possible, actually, given everything you described) that your old boss was genuinely unreasonable, AND you're doing well in a healthier environment. Those aren't contradictory. They're actually exactly what you'd expect if the issue was the situation, not you.

The "quitter who runs away" narrative is your brain trying to make the relief feel unearned. But leaving a bad situation isn't running away. It's just... leaving. You didn't bail before trying—you tried for months, documented the chaos, watched the goalposts move, and made a strategic decision. That's not cowardice. That's recognizing when something isn't fixable.

**Your sister and the boundary:** You said no. No reason, no apology, just "can't, sorry." That's clean. That's exactly what a boundary looks like.

And now it feels terrible, and she's doing the silent treatment, and you're wondering what the point is. So let me say this directly: the point of boundaries isn't that they feel good. The point is that they protect something—your time, your energy, your capacity to show up for your own life. The bad feeling isn't evidence you did it wrong. It's the emotional hangover of going against years of conditioning that told you your job is to manage everyone else's reactions.

Four days of silence from her feels loud right now. But notice: you're surviving it. You're uncomfortable, but you're not falling apart. You haven't texted her seventeen times trying to fix it. That's new. That's different from the you who would've immediately called back and reassured her.

Here's something that might help you sit with this: the discomfort you're feeling right now is the *cost* of the boundary, not a sign it was wrong. And here's the question that matters—is this discomfort more or less than what you'd feel if you'd said yes, gone to dinner, and spent two hours being her emotional support while running on empty? My guess is the silent treatment hurts, but it's a different kind of hurt than the resentment-and-exhaustion hurt you've been carrying.

**"What does the part that keeps trying know?":** You said maybe it doesn't know anything. Maybe it's just stubborn. Maybe you're going through the motions.

Okay. But here's what I notice: you said no to your sister without a five-paragraph justification. You took a new job even though you were scared. You're sitting with discomfort instead of immediately trying to fix it. That's not "going through the motions." That's behavior change happening in real time, even when it doesn't feel meaningful.

The part of you that keeps trying might not have a grand answer. It might just be the part that's tired of living the old way. That's enough. You don't need to believe things will get better in some dramatic way. You just need to keep making slightly different choices and see what happens.

So here's my question: the new job is fine. The sister boundary held, even though it's uncomfortable. What if this is what change actually looks like—not a breakthrough, not feeling fixed, just... things being a little less bad, a little more manageable, while still feeling kind of empty and uncertain? What would it mean to let that be enough for now?

anyway work stuff. ended up hiring someone for that role and they start next week. did the whole interview process myself which was terrifying but my manager said i picked a good candidate so i guess i didnt completely screw it up. still convinced theyre gonna show up and immediately realize i have no idea what im doing and quit but whatever thats probly just the usual brain stuff.

also i did the pottery market thing. like actually did it. spent last weekend sitting at a table with my mediocre bowls while people walked by and occasionally bought something. sold like four pieces which the instructor said was good for a first time but honestly it mostly felt awkward. but also kind of cool? like someone paid actual money for something i made which is insane. the instructor wants me to do it again next month and i said maybe which apparently means yes in her mind now.

sister texted asking if everythings ok because i was "short" with her the other day. which i dont even remember being short i just didnt have a long conversation because i was busy. but now shes doing the thing where she needs reassurance that im not mad at her and i really dont have the energy for it this week. probly the taper making me irritable but also maybe shes being overly sensitive idk.
exchanges.assistant:
**The taper and the "off" days:** A couple of flat, irritable days in week two—that's within the range of what adjustment can look like. Your psychiatrist said keep going and see if it evens out, which suggests she's not alarmed. The question you're really asking is: what if I mess up everything I built?

Here's what I'd offer: the stability you built isn't that fragile. It's not a house of cards that one dose change topples. You've got skills now—boundaries, self-awareness, the ability to notice patterns without being consumed by them. Those don't disappear because your brain chemistry is recalibrating. If the flatness gets worse, or the irritability persists past another week or two, that's information. You tell your psychiatrist, you adjust the plan. But a couple of off days during a taper isn't "messing it up." It's just the process being bumpy, which is normal.

The second-guessing is your threat system doing its thing—scanning for evidence that you made a mistake, that the good stuff was temporary. But you can notice that thought without treating it as true. You're watching. Your psychiatrist is watching. You have a plan. That's not reckless. That's careful.

**Hiring and the new person starting:** You did the whole interview process yourself, terrifying as it was, and your manager said you picked a good candidate. That's real. You're already convinced they'll show up and realize you have no idea what you're doing—but yeah, that's "the usual brain stuff," as you put it. You're onto it now. The thought comes, you label it, you keep going. That's the whole pattern.

When they start next week, you'll onboard them, and it'll probably be awkward and imperfect because that's how first weeks always are. And then it'll settle. They're not going to quit because you're not a flawless manager. They're going to do their job while you figure out how to support them. That's just how this works.

**The pottery market:** You did it. You actually did it. Sat at a table with your "mediocre" bowls, felt awkward, sold four pieces, and someone paid actual money for something you made.

I want to sit with that for a second. A few months ago you said "absolutely not" to this. Then "maybe eventually." Then you asked questions. And now you've done it. That's the whole arc—from reflexive refusal to actually showing up, being uncomfortable, and doing it anyway. The awkwardness doesn't mean it went badly. It means you did something new and it felt unfamiliar. That's exactly what growth feels like from the inside.

The instructor wants you to do it again, and "maybe" apparently means yes to her now. That's fine. You can decide later. But you have proof now that you can do this thing you were sure you couldn't. That's not nothing.

**Your sister and the "short" thing:** She texted asking if everything's okay because you were short with her, and now she needs reassurance that you're not mad. And you don't have the energy for it—maybe the taper irritability, maybe her being overly sensitive, probably some of both.

Here's what I'd offer: you don't have to figure out whose "fault" it is. You were busy, you didn't have a long conversation, she read something into it. That happens. You can acknowledge it simply without turning it into a whole reassurance cycle: "Not mad, just been a low-energy week. Nothing about you."

That's true, it's brief, and it doesn't invite a deep dive. If she pushes for more, you can repeat it: "Really, just tired. We're good." You're not obligated to manage her anxiety about your mood, especially when your mood is being affected by a medication change you're navigating. She can tolerate a little uncertainty about whether you're okay. You've both proven that.

And if this is the taper making you more irritable than usual—that's worth noting for your psychiatrist, but it's also just temporary weather. You don't have to perform patience you don't have right now. You can be a little short and still not be doing anything wrong.

**Where this leaves things:** Taper in progress, new hire starting, pottery market under your belt, sister thing manageable. You're juggling a lot of new and uncertain things at once, and you're a little raw from the dose change. That's a lot. But you're still standing, still noticing the patterns, still doing the things even when they feel hard. The off days don't erase the stability. They're just part of the process of finding out what you need long-term.

Keep watching. Keep reporting. You're doing this right.

exchanges.user:
been about a week since i wrote and honestly things have been kind of rough. the taper thing is definitely affecting me more than i thought it would. like the flat days are getting more frequent and the irritability is worse. snapped at someone on my team yesterday over something small and felt terrible about it after but in the moment i just couldnt deal with their questions. my psychiatrist said we can pause the taper or slow it down even more but now im annoyed because either i push through feeling like crap or i admit i cant handle it and stay on the meds forever. both options suck.

the new hire started and theyre fine i guess but training them is taking up so much energy i dont have right now. keep having to explain things multiple times and pretend to be patient when really i just want everyone to leave me alone. my manager asked how its going and i said fine because what else am i supposed to say, "actually im barely holding it together because i decided to mess with my brain chemistry right before taking on more responsibility"? 

also that pottery market thing from last week. someone emailed me asking if i do custom orders which sounds like a nightmare honestly. like now i have to decide if i want to turn a hobby into actual work or if saying no means im self sabotaging again. the instructor thinks i should do it but she doesnt have to be the one dealing with deadlines and expectations and the inevitable moment when someone realizes my stuff isnt actually that good.

sister has been texting more asking if im ok and i keep saying yeah but honestly i think she can tell somethings off. probly gonna have to actually talk to her about the med thing at some point but really dont want to because then shell worry and make it a whole thing.

anyway. thats where im at. probly shouldve just stayed on the dose that was working but too late now i guess.
exchanges.assistant:
**The taper hitting harder:** The flat days are more frequent, the irritability is worse, and you snapped at someone on your team. That's hard—and it's also exactly the kind of information you need to be tracking. Your psychiatrist offered to pause or slow down, which means she's not seeing this as catastrophic. She's seeing it as the process needing adjustment.

But I hear the bind you're in: push through feeling like crap, or "admit you can't handle it" and stay on meds forever. That framing is doing something brutal to you. Let me try to loosen it a bit.

Pausing the taper isn't admitting defeat. It's not "I can't handle it." It's "this pace isn't working for my brain right now." Those are different things. Some people taper slowly over months. Some people try, find out they need longer-term maintenance, and that's just what their brain requires. Neither of those is failure. The goal was never to get off medication as fast as possible—it was to find out what you need. You're finding out. The data is: this pace is too fast, or this timing is bad, or maybe you need more support than you thought. All of that is just information, not a verdict on your strength or your "realness."

You said "too late now I guess," but it's actually not. You can pause tomorrow. You can slow down. You can go back up and try again later when you're not also onboarding someone new. The stability you built isn't gone—it's just under pressure. You don't have to white-knuckle through this to prove something.

**Work and the new hire:** Training someone while you're running on empty is genuinely hard. You're explaining things multiple times, performing patience you don't have, and telling your manager "fine" because the truth feels too complicated to explain.

Here's what I want to offer: you don't have to tell your manager everything, but you also don't have to pretend you're at 100%. There's a middle ground: "The onboarding is going well but it's taking more energy than I expected. I might need a lighter load on other stuff for a couple weeks." That's not admitting you're falling apart. It's managing your capacity like someone who knows their limits—which is actually a leadership skill.

The snapping at your team member—you felt terrible after, which means you care about how you show up. That's not nothing. If it feels right, you could say something brief to them: "Hey, I was short with you yesterday. Wasn't about you—I've got some stuff going on. Sorry about that." You don't have to explain the taper. You just have to acknowledge the impact. Most people will just say "no worries" and move on.

**The custom pottery order:** Someone wants to pay you for custom work, and you're framing it as: say yes and drown in deadlines and expectations, or say no and be self-sabotaging again.

But there's a third option you're not seeing: say "not right now."

You don't have to decide whether pottery becomes "actual work." You just have to decide whether you want to take *this* order, *right now*, while you're already stretched thin from the taper and the new hire. The answer to that is probably no—not because you're self-sabotaging, but because your plate is full. That's not the same thing.

If you want, you could reply: "Thanks for reaching out—I'm not taking custom orders right now, but I'll keep you in mind if that changes." That's it. Door's not closed forever. You're just not walking through it this week. The instructor might push, but she doesn't know you're in the middle of a medication adjustment and an onboarding. You do. Trust your own read on your capacity.

**Your sister noticing something's off:** She keeps texting, you keep saying you're fine, and you think she can tell. You're avoiding the real conversation because you don't want her to worry and "make it a whole thing."

Here's what I'd offer: you don't have to tell her everything, but you might feel less alone if you tell her something. It doesn't have to be the full story. It could be as simple as: "Yeah, I've been a little off. Adjusting some medication stuff with my doctor. Nothing serious, just makes me tired. I'll let you know if I need anything."

That's honest, it's boundaried, and it gives her something to hold without inviting a deep dive. She might still worry—that's her thing to manage—but you're not lying, and you're not carrying it completely alone. If she does make it a whole thing, you can say: "I appreciate you caring. I'm handling it with my doctor. I'll reach out if I need support."

You've rebuilt this relationship into something more reciprocal. Part of that is letting her know when you're not at your best, without it becoming a crisis for her to solve. That's the next level of what you've been building.

**The "should've just stayed on what was working" thought:** I get why you're there. You were stable, things were good, and now you're in a rough patch because you tried something. But here's what I want you to hold: trying wasn't a mistake. You wanted to know if you could do this without the medication, or with less of it. That's a legitimate thing to find out. The answer might be "not yet" or "not at this pace" or "not without more support." That's not failure. That's just the experiment giving you data.

You're not back to square one. You're in a hard week during an adjustment period. Those are different things.

So here's what I'd suggest: call your psychiatrist and tell her what you told me—the flat days are more frequent, the irritability is worse, you snapped at someone, you're not coping well. Let her adjust the plan. That's what she's there for. You don't have to push through this to prove you're strong enough. You're already strong enough. You're just also human, and your brain needs what it needs.

This part is temporary. The skills you've built aren't going anywhere. You'll get through this stretch and recalibrate. But you don't have to do it the hard way just to prove something to yourself.
